title: 105_s283
content: The Commission on Structural Alternatives for the Federal Courts of Appeals is established to study and make recommendations on the division and structure of the Federal court of appeals system, focusing on the Ninth Circuit, for efficient case disposition while upholding fairness and due process. The Commission on Structural Alternatives for the Federal Courts of Appeals is composed of 8 members appointed by various officials, with vacancies filled in the same manner. The Commission elects a Chair and Vice Chair from its members, with a quorum of four members required for meetings. Compensation details are outlined in Section 3. Members of the Commission, whether Federal officers or not, will be reimbursed for expenses incurred during the performance of their duties, with non-Federal members receiving $200 per diem. Personnel details are outlined in Section 4. The Commission may appoint an Executive Director who will receive compensation not exceeding the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Executive Director can appoint additional personnel without following certain regulations, and their compensation should not exceed the annual maximum rate for a position above GS-15. The Executive Director may also procure experts and consultants. The Executive Director of the Commission may procure personal services of experts and consultants at rates not exceeding the highest level payable under the General Schedule pay rates. The Administrative Office of the United States Courts will provide administrative and financial services for the Commission on a reimbursable basis, while the Federal Judicial Center will provide research services on a reimbursable basis. The Commission is authorized to request information from government entities to carry out its functions. A report must be submitted within a year of the Act's enactment, and the Commission will terminate 90 days after the report submission. The Senate Judiciary Committee must act on the report within 60 days. Authorization of appropriations is also included. SEC. 8. Authorization of appropriations: $500,000 is authorized for the Commission to carry out the Act in fiscal year 1997.
